Design and Analysis of Cluster Randomised Trials
Design and Analysis of Cluster Randomised Trials

Randomised controlled trials are used in many fields to evaluate the impact of interventions. The simplest example is the two arm, individually randomised, parallel design, whereby individuals are randomised to two groups, one of which receives the intervention and the other of which acts as the control, or comparison, group. However, many trials now randomise clusters, rather than individuals, to study arms for a number of reasons including: a desire to capture the population-level impact of an intervention; a potential for individuals in one arm to influence those in another arm (termed “contamination”); or that it is logistically difficult to deliver the intervention to individuals. These are often referred to as cluster randomised trials (CRTs) and are increasingly being used to evaluate programmes and health systems interventions. The design and analysis of such trials requires more complex methods than individually randomised trials. The proposed training course, “Design and analysis of cluster randomised trials”, will be mixture of lectures, small-group seminars and computer practicals, drawing on data from CRTs the course organisers have been involved with.

Mentor-Guided Medical Writing is a method of training researchers and clinicians to write more accurately, effectively, and efficiently. In a class of no more than 10 students (selected for a minimum level of English proficiency), each in turn reads, analyzes, and revises out loud every word and punctuation mark in a sentence of a medical text. The student’s analysis is followed closely by the instructor, who questions the writer at each step about how conclusions were reached or why revisions were proposed. The mentor challenges, encourages, and otherwise leads the student to investigate his or her thoughts about the text. The group then discusses the sentence until all are satisfied that they thoroughly understand the sentence and its implications. The next student then analyzes the next sentence. This process is continued for 3 hours each day with at most only one short break. The process is prolonged and intense because these conditions are necessary to break down old thought processes and to create new, more productive ones.

In this course, no more than 10 students, each of whom is writing a scientific article, will be taught the process of Mentor-Guided Medical Writing for the first 90 minutes of a 3-hour-class each day. In the second 90 minutes, students will pair up and apply the method to each other’s articles, spending 45 minutes on each student’s article. The instructor will circulate among the groups to monitor progress and answer questions. Students will then revised their articles outside of class and bring the revision to the next class, where the process will be repeated. The goal is for each student to have a fairly complete and polished article by the end of the week.
